repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into series by box with and additional series for web crawls.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Observer replaced the Tufts Weekly as the weekly student-published newspaper in 1969. In 1973 "Tufts" was added to the name. It is the official newspaper of record for Tufts University. The Observer receives funding from the student activities budget.
In December 2001, the Observer changed format from a full-size newspaper to a newsmagazine. It continues to be published each Friday during the academic year.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was reorganized from one series to multiple series by box number in May, 2008.
Web sites were crawled by Archive-It. Web crawl information updated in finding aid annually.

processinfo.head: Processing status
processinfo.p: This collection is processed and open for research

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains issues of the Tufts Observer and web crawls documenting its web presence. It covers university news, sports, and events, primarily on the Medford campus. It also includes editorials, announcements and calendar items of events, and nationally syndicated comics. Volume numbering begins with vol. 1 in 1969, and varies in frequency. Sometimes a volume covers one semester, and other times one academic year.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of bound volumes of the Tufts Observer newspaper, dated from January 29, 1969 to May 1, 1970. In 1969, the Observer replaced the Tufts Weekly as the weekly student-published paper. The Observer states that its objective is to be 'the newspaper of record' for Tufts University. The Observer covers current events and university news and sports. Typical features include editorials and opinion pieces, a calendar of events, art and culture articles, creative works, and comics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of loose copies of the Tufts Observer newspapers, dated from September 1, 1994 to November 21, 1996. In 1969, the Observer replaced the Tufts Weekly as the weekly student-published paper. The Observer states that its objective is to be 'the newspaper of record' for Tufts University. The Observer covers current events and university news and sports. Typical features include editorials and opinion pieces, a calendar of events, art and culture articles, creative works, and comics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of loose copies of the Tufts Observer newspaper, dated from December 5, 1996 to March 4, 1999. In 1969, the Observer replaced the Tufts Weekly as the weekly student-published paper. The Observer states that its objective is to be 'the newspaper of record' for Tufts University. The Observer covers current events and university news and sports. Typical features include editorials and opinion pieces, a calendar of events, art and culture articles, creative works, and comics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of loose copies of the Tufts Observer newspaper, dated from September 8, 2000 to October 12, 2001. In 1969, the Observer replaced the Tufts Weekly as the weekly student-published paper. The Observer states that its objective is to be 'the newspaper of record' for Tufts University. The Observer covers current events and university news and sports. Typical features include editorials and opinion pieces, a calendar of events, art and culture articles, creative works, and comics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Presidential Search Committee seeks input from students. Addressing financial aid. Birthright Israel provides free trip. President looks back at changes, improvements, At the close of his Tufts career, John DiBiaggio praises University. Editorial: Financial Aid ought to rethink policies. Learning from mu mistakes. Opinion: In the Unlikely Event of an Emergency, Let There Be Light, This Old Car, Just Say No to Abstinence Education. On the town: Bartley's Burger Cottage Adds Character to Harvard Square, P.F. Chang's Does not Deliver. Jumbos jolted by Worcester State (hockey). Jumbos swim to undefeated streak, Tufts defeats Trinity and Wesleyan to stay at 6-0. Men's basketball bounces to improved record.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Colby, Bowdoin oust Jumbos, Lack of focus troubles Women's Basketball team.

Opinions: Witness an Execution, Plants and Humanity, Sticking to the SAT [Standardized Academics Test]. TASA [Tufts Association of South Asians] prepares for annual culture show. Jumbos exit early from tournament, White Mules knock out Women's Basketball in the first round. Basketball ends with four game skid. Hockey secures first place with win, Jumbos defeat New Hampshire College to raise record to 17-5-1.

Men's basketball finishes season 15-9, without reaching post-season.

Tommy Hilfiger speaks about path to entrepreneurial success. Undergraduates present original research projects at symposium. Students plan activities to foster unity among graduating seniors. Choreographer takes dancers in new direction, head of Tufts Dance Collective Pat Girvin directs his final show. Editorials: Disturbing Coverage, The point of feminism, Behind the hair-rock era. Opinion: The Great Gun Debate, A closer look at Tufts' IR [International Relations] department, Removing SATs only treats the symptom, Losing my religion. Beelzebubs present their audiences with the 'next' best thing to a live show. 3Ps [Pen, Paint, and Pretzels] 'Whack the Bush' in this weekends Overmyer play. Baseball braces for tough season. Sailing starts Spring season at Navy, Nationally-ranked Women's, Co-ed and race teams anticipate strong start. Spring preview: Men's Tennis. Spring Preview: Women's Lacrosse. Spring Preview: Men's Lacrosse.

Baseball drops to .500 overall, remains 2-0 in NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference] conference. Women Athletes prove they have got game.

Housing policies undergo changes, problems remain. Tufts launches sexual assault help line. English professor encourages students to criticize, In his twenty-second year, Lee Edelman praises community, students. Editorials: Cooperation makes it happen, Sex, ads and MTV. Opinion: Finding you niche, 10 Reasons why we need a gradeless institution, Campaign finance reform gives power to the people, A Medical Nightmare. Jumbos Bash Buchaneers. 17-3 [baseball]. Professor searches for more efficient ways to store electrical energy. Professor takes learning beyond the classroom, Lee Vigilant makes impression on students in many programs. TCU [Tufts Community Union] presidential candidates publish platforms. Editorials: A pathetic turn-out, [David] Attanasio missed the joke?, What's in a name? Opinion: Building Community a all costs. The Source: Primarily bigots. Fletcher replies to unfounded claims. Softball splits double header, [Jodie] Moreau pitches gem to keep Jumbos undefeated in NESCAC [New England Schools and Colleges Athletic Conference]. [Jon] Bram and [Sonny] Kathpalia Triumph for tennis, Strong performance by freshmen put Jumbos one win from .500.

Year in Review: 2000-2001: A year marked by increased political activism and conflicting ideologies. [Johanna] Neumann achieves national acclaim. Lacrosse rocked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of loose copies of the Tufts Observer news magazine, dated from November 9, 2001 to May 23, 2004. In 1969, the Observer replaced the Tufts Weekly as the weekly student-published paper. The Observer states that its objective is to be 'the newspaper of record' for Tufts University. The Observer covers current events and university news and sports. Typical features include editorials and opinion pieces, a calendar of events, art and culture articles, creative works, and comics.
